titleStmt.title: Top Quark at the Upgraded Tevatron to Probe New Physics

analytic.title: Top Quark at the Upgraded Tevatron to Probe New Physics

biblStruct.note: arXiv:hep-ph/9802305v1 12 Feb 1998 1 Talk presented by Jin Min Yang at the Top Quark Working Group at the Workshop on Physics at the First Muon Collider and at the Front End of a Muon Collider, Nov. 6-9, 1997, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, to appear in the proceedings. 1

abstract.p: This talk is a brief review of the recent studies on probing new physics through single top quark processes and probing exotic top quark decays at the upgraded Tevatron.

figure.trash: Top Quark at the Upgraded Tevatron to Probe New Physics 1 Jin Min Yang a,b,2 and A. Datta b , M. Hosch b , C. S. Li c , R. J. Oakes a , K. Whisnant b , Bing-Lin Young b , X. Zhang

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The exceedingly heavy top quark is believed to be more sensitive to new physics than others. The upgraded Tevatron will provide a good opportunity to study top quark properties. Apart from the dominant top pair production which tests the top's QCD properties, the single top productions [1] are also interesting to study since they involve the electroweak interaction and can, therefore, be used to probe new physics in top's electroweak couplings. Analyses show that new physics effects that produce larger than 16% effect on the single top cross section should should be detectable at the upgraded Tevatron [2]. On the other hand, since top events will increase significantly at the upgraded Tevatron, it is interesting to search for exotic top decays predicted by new physics models. This talk is a brief review of some recent studies on the ability of single top quark production at the upgraded Tevatron to probe new physics as well as the possibility of observing the exotic decay mode of the top quark predicted by Minimal Supersymmetric Model (MSSM). About the SUSY effects in top pair production, we refer to [3] and will not discuss them further.

div.head: Model-independent Analysis for New Physics in Single Top Production
div.p: Since no direct signal of new particles has been observed so far, it is very likely that the only observable effects of new physics at energies not too far above the SM energy scale could be in the form of new interactions affecting the couplings of the third-family quarks, and the untested sectors of the Higgs and gauge bosons. In this spirit, the new physics effects can be expressed as non-standard terms in an effective

Lagrangian describing the interactions among third-family quarks, the Higgs and gauge bosons, which were enumerated in [4, 5, 6]. In the following we pick out those which affect single top production at the Tevatron.
Two typical operators which contribute to LEP I and LEP II observables, σ t ¯ t and A t F B at NLC and σ t ¯ b at the Tevatron are [5]

div.p: Φq are found to be negligibly small [5], while the effects of O
So the effects of O qW may still be observable at LEP II, NLC and the upgraded Tevatron.
The following dimension-six CP-violating operators can give rise to transverse polarization asymmetry of top quark in single top production (u + ¯ d → t+ ¯ b, ¯ u+ d → ¯ t + b) at the Tevatron [6]:

figure.trash: ¯ O qW = i ¯ q L γ µ τ I D ν q L − D ν q L γ µ τ I q L W I µν , (5) ¯ O tW Φ = i (¯ q L σ µν τ I t R ) Φ − (D µ Φ) † (D µ t R q L ) (6)

div.p: N t ( ±ˆ¯ t ( ±îs the number of t( ¯ t) quarks polarized in the direction ±ˆssuming m t = 175 GeV, we obtain the asymmetry at hadron level as [6]

figure.trash: A(ˆ y) =    −0.41 C qW −2C tW Φ −g 2 C Dt /2 (Λ/1 TeV) 2 at √ s = 2 TeV −0.84 C qW −2C tW Φ −g 2 C Dt /2 (Λ/1 TeV) 2 at √ s = 4 TeV (8) Assume an observable level of ten percent of this asymmetry, the upgraded Tevatron will probe C qW − 2C tW Φ − g 2 C Dt /2 (Λ/1 TeV) 2 to 1/4 for √ s = 2 TeV 1/8 for √ s = 4 TeV (9)

div.p: This means that with a new physics scale at the order of 1 TeV, the further upgraded Tevatron can probe the coupling strength down to the level of 0.1.

div.head: Probing SUSY in Single Top Production
div.p: In the R-parity Conserving MSSM, we found that within the allowed range of squark and gluino masses the supersymmetric QCD corrections can enhance the cross section by a few percent [8]. The Yukawa corrections [8] to single top quark production at the Tevatron can amount to more than a 15% reduction in the production cross section relative to the tree level result in the general two-Higgs-doublet model, and a 10% enhancement in the minimal supersymmetric model for the smallest allowed tan β (≃ 0.25). The supersymmetric electroweak corrections [8] to the cross section are at most a few percent for tan β > 1, but can exceed 10% for tan β < 1. So the combined effects of SUSY QCD, SUSY EW, and the Yukawa couplings in the R-parity Conserving MSSM can exceed 10% for the smallest allowed tan β (≃ 0.25) but are only a few percent for tan β > 1. In the R-parity violating MSSM, the processes induced by R-violating couplings are [9, 10] λ ′ : u ¯ d → ˜ l → t + ¯ b, (s − channel)

figure.trash: (10) λ ′′ : u ¯ d → t + ¯ b, (t − channel) (11) λ ′′ : cd → ˜ s → tb, (s − channel) (12) λ ′′ : cs → ˜ d → tb, (s − channel) (13)
figure.figDesc: Their signature are an energetic charged lepton, missing E T , and double b-quark jets. The backgrounds are (1) q ¯ q ′ → W * → t ¯ b, (2) the quark-gluon process qg → q ′ t ¯ b with a W-boson as an intermediate state in either the t-channel or the s-channel of a subdiagram; (3) processes involving a b-quark in the initial state, bq(¯ q) → tq
figure.trash: ′ (¯ q ′ ) and gb → tW ; (4) W b ¯ b; (5) W jj; and (6) t ¯ t → W − W + b ¯ b. For the upgraded Tevatron (LHC), the basic cuts are p l T ≥ 20 GeV, p b T ≥ 20(35) GeV, p miss T ≥ 20(30) GeV, η b , η l ≤ 2.5(3

div.p: ) and ∆R jj , ∆R jl ≥ 0.4. Also we required reconstructed top quark mass M(bW ) to lie within the mass range |M(bW ) − m t | < 30 GeV, which can reduce the backgrounds W b ¯ b and W jj efficiently. The number of signal events required for discovery of a signal is S ≥ 5 √ B. For the s-channel process u + ¯ d → ˜ l → t + ¯ b induced by λ ′ , the histogram of the differential cross section versus the invariant mass of the t ¯ b system over the bin size of 10 GeV is shown in Fig.2 of Ref. [9]. The resonance behavior is already manifested. Because of their narrow widths, for each slepton the contributions of the λ ′ -couplings are negligible for a couple of bins away from the resonance. This will help to identify the signal of the slepton production. The value of λ

versus the slepton mass for u ¯ d → ˜ l → t ¯ b to be observable under the criteria S ≥ 5 √ B is shown in Fig.4 of Ref. [10], which show that the LHC can do better than the upgraded Tevatron in further probing the couplings, especially for higher mass sleptons.

For the s-channel process cd → ˜ s → tb induced by λ ′′ couplings, the value of λ ′′ 212 λ ′′ 332 versus strange-squark mass for it to be observable under the criteria S ≥ 5 √ B is shown in Fig.1 of Ref.[10], which show that both the LHC and the upgraded Tevatron can efficiently probe the relevant couplings, and the LHC serves a more powerful probe than the upgraded Tevatron.

For the s-channel process cs → ˜ d → tb induced by λ ′′ , The value of λ ′′ 212 λ ′′ 331 versus down-squark mass for it to be observable under the criteria S ≥ 5 √ B is shown in Fig.3 of Ref. [10], which show that this process cannot be probed as efficiently as cd → ˜ s → tb because of the relative suppression of the strange quark structure function compared to the valence down quark.

div.head: Searching for Exotic Top Decay Modes
div.p: The FCNC Decays in the SM, R-conserving MSSM [11] and R-violating MSSM [12] are given by
The FCNC top decays in R-violating MSSM might be observable at the upgraded Tevatron since for integrated luminosity of 10 (100) fb −1 , the detection sensitivity is [13]

Let us look at the top decay to light stop, t → ˜ t 1 ˜ χ 0 1 , in the framework of Rconserving MSSM with the lightest neutralino being the LSP. the parameters involved in Γ(t → ˜ t 1 ˜ χ 0 1 ) are M ˜ t 1 , M 2 , M 1 , µ, tan β. In the region of parameter space allowed by R b data and the eeγγ + E T event[14], we obtain [15] 0.07 ≤ B(t → ˜ t 1 ˜ χ 0 1 ) ≤ 0.50. The dorminant decay of a light stop is t 1 → c ˜ χ 0 1 . This will give a new final state in t ¯ t production:

p.formula: t ¯ t → W b¯ c ˜ χ 0 1 ˜ χ 0 1 .

div.p: Its signature is an energetic charged lepton, one b-quark jet, one light c-quark jet, plus missing E T from the neutrino and the unobservable χ

figure.trash: 0 1 ′ s. The potential SM backgrounds are (1) bq(¯ q) → tq ′ (¯ q ′ ), (2) q ¯ q ′ → W * → t ¯ b; (3) W b ¯ b; (4) W jj; (5) t ¯ t → W − W + b ¯ b; (6) gb → tW and (7) qg → q ′ t ¯ b. Besides the basic cuts we impose a cut on transverse mass m T = (P l T + P miss T ) 2 − ( P l T + P miss T ) 2 > 90 GeV. Then we found (1) this final state is unobservable at Run 1 with √ s = 1.8 TeV and L = 0.1 fb −1 , (2)
figure.figDesc: Run 2 with √ s = 2 TeV and L = 10 fb −1 can either discover this final state or provide the additional strong constraint given approximately by

div.p: If charged Higgs is light enough, t → H + b is also possible; we refer to [16] for its phenomenological implications at Tevatron.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: (1) Single top quark processes at upgraded Tevatron can be meaningfuly used to probe new physics; (2) The FCNC top decays t → cV and top decay to light stop t → ˜ t 1 ˜ χ 0 1 predicted by R-violating MSSM might be observable at upgraded Tevatron, else further constraints can be set on the relevant couplings.
